text: The United States has increased its operations in Iraq and Syria, but Mr. Lindsay Graham, R-S.C., says the army is shrinking. On Sunday morning in CNN, President Barack Obama's Graham criticized what he said about "half measures" in the frustration of the terrorist group, the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. While Obama focused on avoiding sending combat troops to the Middle East, Graham said that it might be necessary to have up to 4,000 troops. The issue of military size reappeared when host Candy Crowley asked Graham what his plans were if the Republicans controlled the Senate in November. The replacement of budgets using segregation was priority 1. 1. "I've just heard a part about the spread of Ebola all over Africa," he said. "We're cutting the CDC budget, the national health budget. We're taking the military budget under arrest down to the smallest army since 1940, the smallest navy since 1915. We're destroying the Intelligence Committee." There's a lot there, but the idea that the U.S. military -- the largest military in the world in terms of spending -- is as small as it was almost a century ago has drawn our attention. We found Graham had exact numbers for the army and the Navy. However, the current comparison of the army with its counterparts in the past decades compares apples to oranges due to massive growth in technology and public capabilities. The figures cited by Graham refer to the number of ground troops and vessels, the traditional method of measuring the size of the army and navy, respectively, as stated by Alex Roland, a professor of military history at Duke University. Graham ' s staff referred to a letter written by former Defence Minister Leon Banita in 2011. Graham and Sin John McCain, R-Aries, both supporters of strong funding for the Ministry of Defence, requested the message in the midst of the Congressional budget talks in autumn 2011 that led to the isolation legislation. In the letter, Banita said, "In the face of these large cuts, we will have to sharply reduce the size of the army. Approximately 10 years after these reductions, we will have the smallest ground force since 1940, the smallest number of ships since 1915, and the smallest air force in its history." As far as we know, Banita's assessment is accurate. The army has already begun to reduce the number of soldiers to 440,000 to 450,000 -- less than its last rise in time of war of 570,000, according to the defence review conducted by the Ministry of Defence in 2014 every four years. (These reductions are the result of the end of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and are not budgeted as part of the isolation.) In the future, if the cutbacks on the seclusion pattern enter into force in fiscal year 2016, the number of troops is likely to decrease to 420,000. This is the lowest number of soldiers since 1940. Before the entry into force of the project later that year, there were approximately 264,000 soldiers in the army. By moving to the Navy, there are currently 289 deployable warships. According to the quadrennial review, there will be an estimated fleet of 234 ships in fiscal year 2019. This is the lowest number of ships since 1915 -- two years before the United States was involved in World War I. That year, the Navy had 231 deployable vessels. In 2016, it jumped to 245 ships. But we have learned from experts that comparing the number of troops and ships does not say much about military strength. We have taken Graham ' s claim context to many experts, who have told us that comparing the United States army in 2014 with the United States army in the early 20th century is irrelevant. Because of technological advances, today's military vessels and forces have greater capabilities than they did in world wars. "One of the reasons for the decline in size -- the Army and the Navy -- is that we are now relying on technology much more than just numbers," said Roland, the military history expert from Duke. The question is not how to compare our army in 1940 or our freedom in 1915, but how to compare our potential enemies in 2014. We are heads and shoulders above them." For example, the Navy did not have any aircraft carriers in 1915, but now has an active fleet of 10. David E. Johnson, a political scientist at Rand, estimated that only four modern aircraft carriers would have capabilities equal to those of the entire Navy before World War I. At that time, the army also did not have radar, satellites, computers and submarines for almost undetectable ballistic missiles, unmanned aerial vehicles and other advanced technology that would allow the army to do more with fewer troops. Also, in terms of military spending for other countries, the United States accounts for 37 per cent of total world military spending. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, China is pursuing 11 per cent of global spending, starting in 2013. In other words, the United States spends as much on its army as the next eight to twelve countries that spend more on defence together. The war has also changed, as Johnson said.
